info.game_comments: Alex returns to conducting contestant interviews from near contestant lecterns.

(1, 1).clue: He published the first edition of "Leaves of Grass" at his own expense & even set some of the type for it

(2, 1).clue: Mark Harmon investigates all crimes involving U.S. Navy & Marine Corps personnel on this drama

(3, 1).clue: Matt Armendariz has a whole book devoted to foods "on a" this! like hot dogs, fried mozzarella & chicken satay

(4, 1).clue: Witch hunting was more fashionable in this city 16 miles N.E. of Boston than in its West Coast counterpart

(5, 1).clue: It just came to me out of the blue--it's a measure of cloth, usually 40 yards

(1, 2).clue: Upon this woman's death in 1886, her sister Lavinia found nearly 1,000 poems hidden away in her bureau

(2, 2).clue: Hawkeye & Trapper John shared a tent called The Swamp on this sitcom

(3, 2).clue: In a twist on the meat dish, "How to Cook Everything Vegetarian" has a recipe for chili non this

(4, 2).clue: This city that lies about 125 miles from the mouth of the Savannah River is known for a certain golf course

(5, 2).clue: For my daughter's suitors' reference, my shotgun has a bore just under 3/4 of an inch wide, so it's a 12-this

(6, 2).clue: To litter with things in a disorderly manner

(1, 3).clue: Shortly after becoming engaged to Sarah Shelton, he fell ill in a Baltimore tavern & died 4 days later on October 7, 1849

(2, 3).clue: In April 2009 the doors of Chicago's County General Hospital closed to TV viewers as this show ended

(3, 3).clue: In "The Lady & Sons Savannah Country Cookbook", Paula Deen has a section on these, including Confederate bean

(4, 3).clue: You'll find the University of Missouri's main campus in this city--the one in Missouri, not in South Carolina

(5, 3).clue: Please tell us you know that a hoppus foot measures this building material--& tell us chop chop

(1, 4).clue: This family of poets born in & around Boston includes Amy, James Russell & Robert

(2, 4).clue: Ponch & Jon were motorcycle cops on this '70s police drama

(3, 4).clue: This chef whose last name is an anagram of bread published a book "On Bread" in 1973

(4, 4).clue: Home of the Cascade Falls, this city in Michigan (not Mississippi) is also called "The Rose City"

(5, 4).clue: Used in surveying, this unit is equal to one hundredth of a chain

(1, 5).clue: In "Concord Hymn", he wrote, "Here once the embattled farmers stood, and fired the shot heard round the world"

(2, 5).clue: The beer-drinking MacKenzie brothers were a staple on this comedy show whose full name once included "Network 90"

(3, 5).clue: This Bravo star & former "New York Housewife" offers up some easy & healthy recipes in "The Skinnygirl Dish"

(4, 5).clue: It's the seat of Illinois' Logan County & shares its name with the capital of a different Midwest state

(5, 5).clue: 1 of the 2 units, each 3 letters long & starting with "R", that measure radiation exposure from X-rays

(6, 5).clue: This type of heavenly group seen here is held together by mutual attraction

(1, 1).clue: It's the result of one or more multiplications

(3, 1).clue: In 8-ball the balls are racked in this shape, with the 8 ball in the center

(4, 1).clue: Joan of Arc became the maid of this city when she led French troops to victory there in May 1429

(5, 1).clue: Used to transport small loads like lawn dirt, it's a cart with 1 tire & a shallow body, held & pushed by handles

(6, 1).clue: Seen here are 1960s designs by engineer James Drake, who made use of RAND's Santa Monica location to become the father of this sport

(1, 2).clue: When he wasn't busy rubaiyating, this 11th century renaissance man wrote a pioneering work on algebra

(3, 2).clue: The bed, or top, of a billiard table is usually made of this rock & can weigh as much as 800 pounds

(4, 2).clue: On May 10, 1981 France elected as president this socialist who then nationalized most of the private banks

(5, 2).clue: It can be a sled or toboggan, someone riding in one, or a mat you put under a drink

(6, 2).clue: RAND research culminated in a 1987 treaty on these 3-element compounds that break down the ozone layer

(1, 3).clue: The prefix "mega" denotes 10 to the 6th power; "giga", 10 to this power

(2, 3).clue: Shallow, crossable part of a river

(3, 3).clue: This white object gave its name to a bald "Dick Tracy" villain

(4, 3).clue: In a July 6, 2003 referendum, this Mediterranean island narrowly defeated a plan for limited autonomy

(5, 3).clue: It's a 2-wheeled wagon used to carry artillery ammunition; in song, they "go rolling along"

(6, 3).clue: In the first book on this, computers doing tasks associated with human intellect, 6 chapters had been RAND reports

(1, 4).clue: Jean Poncelet's work on conic sections helped found the "projective" form of this branch of mathematics

(3, 4).clue: Snooker is played with 15 balls of this color & 6 balls of other colors

(4, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew shows a map on the monitor.)  In June 1940, France was split into German-occupied France & Vichy France; 2 1/2 years later, Germany gained control of a large part of continental France;  Italy gained most of the area east of this river

(5, 4).clue: A color & a woman's name combine in this term for a police wagon

(6, 4).clue: Packet switching, the basic idea of the Internet, came from '60s research on communications in case of this awful event

(1, 5).clue: Mathematicians disagree as to whether zero belongs in this set of numbers denoted N

(3, 5).clue: In 1845 this firm manufactured its first pool table for a Cincinnati meatpacker; it's sold millions of tables since then

(4, 5).clue: The October 1415 battle of this fortress, lost to the English, actually took place in a nearby muddy field

(5, 5).clue: This Olympic sport gets its name from the metal sled introduced in the 1890s & what some people thought it resembled

(6, 5).clue: The field called this "theory", which has influenced economics & other disciplines, was expanded at RAND in the '40s

(0, 0).clue: Previously done by the Trapp Family, this song about an instrumentalist was a Top 40 hit every December from 1958 to 1962
